HABITAT: Sandstone rockhouses and ledges along clifflines.
DIAGCHARS: This goldenrod has white hairs on the stem. It is somewhat similar to S. flexicaulis in having ovate to elliptic shaped leaves distributed along the stem; the base is more subcordate (slightly heart-shaped). It is found in rockhouses and along rocky ledges.

HABITAT: Sandstone rockhouses and ledges along clifflines.

HABITAT: Moist sand in mesophytic forest, wet openings along stream on dip slope.
DIAGCHARS: This species is distinguished by the copious glands on the achenes and the leaves have a viscid (sticky) underside.  The sharply toothed (albeit few toothed)  leaves are cauline (on the stem) and are over 6 cm long and 2 cm wide. The heads are corymbiform with white to pink rays (the outer flowers in the head).  It is restricted to the Cumberland Mountains.

HABITAT: Rich forests, ranging from moist forests to rather dry oak forests (Weakley 1998).
FLOWERING: Mid April to mid June. Fruiting Period: Early June to late July.
DIAGCHARS: Herbaceous mint with opposite, ovate-oblong (to 20 cm) leaves in 2 to 3 pairs, usually near the base of the inflorescence, giving a whorled apppearance. The pink-tinged flowers (0.6-0.8 inches long) are in a single terminal panicle. They are bilabiate (two-lipped) and the lower lip is fringed; four stamens present. It flowers earlier than  C. canadensis  (Apr-Jun versus Jul-Sep) and it can extend into drier woods (Campbell, 2012).

HABITAT: Moist woods and thickets, associated with limestone derived soils.
DIAGCHARS: The flowers are swollen on one side of the base and generally yellowish green (rather than orangish).  Leaves are glaucous on the lower side (below) and green above.  A glandular hypanthium distinguishes it from other varieties.

HABITAT: Moist woods and thickets, associated with limestone derived soils.

HABITAT: Moist mesophytic woods, mountain and stream terraces, mesic rock faces, and recent clearings.
DIAGCHARS: Leaves are cauline (on the stem), 2 or 3 in number, cordate (heartshape) and clasping.  Flowers are terminal with 4 white spreading tepals, the perianth (petals and sepals together) 1-3 mm long.  Fruit is pale red.

HABITAT: Mesic forests.
DIAGCHARS: Stemless perennial herb, rhizomatous, scapose (the flowering stem and leaves arising from the rhizome).  The petiole erect to 5 dm and the leaves are ternate (divided into three), each division pinnately 3-5 foliate.  Leaflets are lance-elliptic generally, finely serrate and about 15 cm long. The lateral leaflets are assymetric at the base.  Fruit is black.

HABITAT: Openings in seasonally moist forests, prairies and roadsides.
FLOWERING: Early June to late July. Fruiting Period: Early August to late October.
DIAGCHARS: This lily has flowers that are erect rather than nodding. The tepals are abruptly narrowed near the base (clawed).  It is found on woodland borders or associated with grass dominated areas.

HABITAT: Rich dry or mesic woods.
DIAGCHARS: Large (7-15 dm) perennial with narrow to broadly oblanceolate  leaves. Stem pubescent and unbranched.  Flowers are dark maroon, 6-9 mm, in a terminal panicle and the rachis pubescent.  Tepals are tapering and without glands.

HABITAT: Swamps, bogs and streamsides.
FLOWERING: Early July to late September. Fruiting Period: Early July to late August.
DIAGCHARS: The lower leaf blades and sheaths of this bulrush are purplish and the top of the culm is scabrous. Also, stems do not come from the ground in clusters but as single stems. The styles are divided into 3 parts (trifid). Scales in the inflorescence are dark (brown to black) with a green midstripe. Spikelets are not obviously drooping.

HABITAT: Reported in meadows and damp woods; in KY, prairies and open woodlands.
DIAGCHARS: The flowers are yellowish white and appear as a long tube. The plants are glabrous (without hair). The length of the calyx lobes are less than 1.5 cm, ovate to deltoid in shape and keeled on the back.

HABITAT: Damp (although sometimes seasonally only)  acid soil of open woods and grassy openings.
DIAGCHARS: The spike of white flowers is tightly spiraled, appearing in several ranks rather than a simple single spiral.  Leaves present at flowering.  The flowers are light yellow (not deeply colored). The lateral sepals ascend and are 7.5 mm long/  The lip is arcuate recurved (arched up and then the tip down) and with an erose or wavy margin.

HABITAT: Bogs, swamps, savannas (Weakley 2011); dry or wet acid soil;  in KY, mossy seeps.
DIAGCHARS: This small (1-4 dm) plant of wet prairies and sphagnum bogs has opposite (as opposed to alternate in B. paniculata) leaves that are reduced to scales along the stem.  Petals are oblong, denticulate and abruptly narrowed to  rounded with a minute tip (mucro).

HABITAT: Mesic ravine forests.
DIAGCHARS: Yellow flowers are erect  and the tepals (the "petals") do not have red or red/brown spots.   The inner tepals have noticeable auricles at the base.  The extended style (bearing the stigma) persists to form a long beak on the fruit.

TYPE: Reaches 1-3 feet in height and has clover-like leaves, and yellow flowers (Foster and Duke 1990). Racemes are numerous and leaves tend to be dark bluish-green (Rhoads and Block 2000).
HABITAT: Sandhills, pine flatwoods, xeric woodlands, ridges, woodland edges, and roadbanks (Weakley 2011).
FLOWERING: Early April to late August. Fruiting Period: Early July to late November.
DIAGCHARS: This species can reach 1-3 feet in height and has clover-like leaves, and yellow flowers (Foster and Duke 1990). Racemes are numerous and leaves tend to be dark bluish-green (Rhoads and Block 2000).  Leaves are widely branched with leaflets 1-3 (sometimes to 4) cm long, inflorescences numerous, the flowers yellow and 8-16 mm long, pods small 8-15 m.

HABITAT: Dry to moist open soil, thickets, woods, and bogs, moist open ephemeral streamheads, pond margins.
DIAGCHARS: The orange/yellow flowers distinguish this species from most other orchids.  The lip is fringed and the spur is long (18-28 mm). The lower leaves are narrow (less than 2 cm), strap-like and up to 20 cm in length.   Platantheras in general have the upper two petals merged into a hood that extends over the column.  The lateral sepals area spreading.

HABITAT: Forested and open wetlands, shorelines.
DIAGCHARS: Zigzag iris is distinguished from other blue iris species by its short flowering stems, which are shorter than the leaves (to 35 cm) and often hidden among the leaves. Also the ovary and capsule are 6-angled (Jones 2005).
